case_name: Madhya Pradesh Industries Corporation Ltd. v. Gwalior Shasakiya Audogik Karamehari Sangh

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1907 of 1970 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1907 of 1970,

facts.text: Appeal by certificate from order dated October 30, 1969 of Madhya Pradesh High Court Gwalior Bench.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by certificate from the order dated October 30, 1969, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Gwalior Bench  in Civil Misc.

facts.text: Order in Civil Misc. Petition No. 16 of 1968 by Madhya Pradesh High Court.

anchor.surface_text: High Court  Gwalior Bench  in Civil Misc. Petition No. 16 of 1968.

facts.text: Prior to April 1, 1963, three undertakings owned and managed by Madhya Pradesh State: Gwalior Engineering Works, Gwalior Potteries, Gwalior Leather Factory and Gwalior Tannery, Morar.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to April 1, 1963, three undertakings namely, Gwalior Engineering Works,  2  Gwalior Potteries, and  3  Gwalior Leather Factory and Gwalior Tannery, Morar, were owned and managed by the Madhaya Pradesh State.

facts.text: Employees of the three undertakings were in service of Madhya Pradesh State Government prior to transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The employees in these undertakings were in the service of the Madhya Pradesh State Government.

facts.text: Undertakings transferred to Madhya Pradesh Industries Corporation Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: These undertakings were transferred to the Madhya Pradesh Industries Corporation Ltd., hereinafter called the Corporation.

facts.text: Employees ceased to be in service of State Government and became employees of the Corporation after transfer.

anchor.surface_text: The employees of these undertakings thus ceased to be in the service of the State Government and became employees of the Corporation.

facts.text: Government of Madhya Pradesh made offer to employees on February 16, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On February 16, 1963 the Government of Madhya Pradesh had made an offer to the employees ,of the. three undertakings which was as follows

facts.text: Transfer of undertakings effective from April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: to the Madhya Pradesh State Industries Corporation  hereinafter referred to as the said Corporation  with effect from 1st day of April, 1963.

facts.text: Offer stated present pay, scale, conditions of service and benefits not affected by transfer.

anchor.surface_text: Your present pay and scale, and other companyditions of service and benefits to which you are at present entitled will number be affected by transfer.

facts.text: Transfer of services not treated as interruption in service.

anchor.surface_text: The transfer of your services will number be treated as an interruption in your service.

facts.text: Employees entitled to leave and benefits as continuation of uninterrupted service under Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: In other words you win be entitled to leave and other benefits on the same basis as if your services under the State Corporation was a companytinuation of your total uninterrupted services under the said undertakings,,

facts.text: Employees required to inform acceptance by March 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The person to whom the letter was addressed was required to let the General Manager of each of the Undertakings know by the 20th day of March 1963 whether he agreed

facts.text: Offer accepted by employees of the three undertakings.

anchor.surface_text: This offer had been accepted by the employees of the three undertakings.

facts.text: Gwalior Shasakiya Audogik Karamehari Sangh filed application under s 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act on August 28, 1968.

anchor.surface_text: However Gwalior Shasakiya Audogik Karamehari Sangh, Lashkar, Gwalior, filed an application under s 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, on August 28, 1968

facts.text: Union claimed dearness allowance at same rate and basis as paid by Madhya Pradesh State Government to its employees.

anchor.surface_text: claiming that the dearness allowance should be paid by the Corporation at the same rate and on the same basis on which the Madhya Pradesh State Government, was paying this allowance to its employees.

facts.text: Corporation paid same rates of DA as State Government for about two years then declined.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that the Corporation had paid the same rates as were being paid by the Madhya Pradesh State Government for about two years but later on the. Corporation declined to pay the same rates of Dearness Allowance to its employees.

facts.text: Labour Court did not accede to union's contention on dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court did number accede to the companytention of the Union of the employees that they were entitled to dearness allowance at the same rates

facts.text: R.C. Sharma, Secretary of the Union, filed petition under Art. 226 of Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: A petition was filed under Art. 226 of the Constitution by R. C. Sharma the Secretary of the Union mentioned before.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court dismissed the Art. 226 petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed that petition.

facts.text: High Court relied on earlier decision in Misc. Petition No. 237 of 1968 decided on March 26, 1969.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court relied on an earlier decision given by it in Misc. Petition No, 237 of 1968 decided on March 26, 1969.

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court's interpretation of condition No. 2.

anchor.surface_text: We are in entire agreement with this view of the High Court.

facts.text: Supreme Court finds no ground to interfere with High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: We find numberground on which we can interfere in the order, of the High Court.
under s 33C 2  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947

if condition No. 2 was to be read as securing to a transferred employee benefits which the Government might in future confer upon its employees that would contradict condition No. 1

concepts.interpretation: Conditions of offer must be read harmoniously; condition 2 cannot be interpreted to contradict condition 1 by extending future benefits not secured at time of transfer

issues.text: whether under the terms of the offer made and accepted by the employees, they are entitled to the same dearness allowance as is being paid by the State Government to its employees

anchor.surface_text: The short. question involved in this appeal is whether under the terms of the offer made and accepted by the employees, they are entitled to the same dearness allowance as is being paid by the State Government to its emp

anchor.surface_text: claiming that the dearness allowance should be paid by the Corporation at the same rate and on the same basis on which the Madhya Pradesh State Government, was paying this allowance to its employees.

arguments.court_reasoning: Labour Court did not accede to the contention.

arguments.claim: The second term or condition entitled them to the same dearness allowance which the employees of the Madhya Pradesh State Government were getting.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Union was that the second term or condition entitled them to the same dearness allowance which the employees of the Madhya Pradesh State Government were getting.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: he said undertakings. The High Court relied on an earlier decision given by it in Misc. Petition No, 237 of 1968 decided on March 26, 1969. According

arguments.court_reasoning: Term confined to effect of transfer on service, no interruption.

arguments.claim: Condition No. 2 should be so interpreted as to confer on the employees of the Corporation the same benefits to which the employees of the State became entitled in the course of subsequent years.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. C. K. Daphtary who appeared for the appellant tried to persuade us that condition No. 2 should be so interpreted as to confer on the employees of the Corporation the same benefits to which the employees of the State became entitled in the course of subsequent years.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed at the time of transfer. We are in entire agreement with this view

arguments.court_reasoning: We are unable to construe condition No. 2 in the manner suggested.

arguments.claim: Leave and other benefits under condition No. 2 are those depending upon length of service like gratuity, pension; fiction of continuity not to apply future government service changes.

anchor.surface_text: According to that decision leave and other benefits that were secured under condition No. 2 were leave and such benefits which depended upon the length of service, e.g., gratuity, pension etc. The object of creating a fiction of continuity of service was not to make the Corporation employees Government employees and to make applicable to them any change effected in the conditions of service of government employees but what was intended was to secure to the transferred employees leave and benefits depending upon the length of service by making their service fictionally uninterrupted.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ver benefits an employee of the State Government were to get in future the employees of the Corporat

arguments.court_reasoning: We are in entire agreement with this view of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Condition No. 1 makes clear that subsisting pay, scale, conditions of service and benefits at the time of transfer would not be affected.

anchor.surface_text: The first term made it quite clear that when the employees of the erstwhile undertakings of the State would join the service of the Corporation their subsisting pay and scale and other conditions of service and benefits to which they were entitled at that time would not be affected by the transfer.

arguments.claim: Condition No. 2 confined to no interruption in service for leave and length-based benefits.

anchor.surface_text: Now this term or condition was confined only to the question of the effect of the transfer on the service of an employee. It was made clear that the transfer of service would not be treated as an interruption in his service. This - was amplified by saying, you will be entitled to leave and other benefits on the same basis as if your services under the State Corporation was a continuation of your total uninterrupted services under the said undertakings.

arguments.claim: Reading condition No. 2 to secure future government benefits would contradict condition No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the High Court in the earlier judgment if condition No. 2 was to be read as securing to a transferred employee benefits which the Government might in future confer upon its employees that would contradict condition No. 1 which secured only such benefits to which a transferred employee was entitled at the time of transfer.

arguments.claim: Condition No. 2 secures no suffering in length of service and uninterrupted benefits due to transfer.

anchor.surface_text: All that that condition secured was that the employees should not suffer in the length of their service and in the enjoyment of the benefits which an uninterrupted service confers on them because of the transfer of their service from the State Government to the Corporation.

holdings.text: under the terms of the offer made and accepted by the employees, they are entitled to the same dearness allowance as is being paid by the State Government to its employees: No

anchor.surface_text: The short. question involved in this appeal is whether under the terms of the offer made and accepted by the employees, they are entitled to the same dearness allowance as is being paid by the State Government to its emp

holdings.reasoning_summary: Offer conditions preserve existing benefits at transfer time and ensure service continuity only for length-based benefits, not future changes

holdings.text: The first term made it quite clear that when the employees of the erstwhile undertakings of the State would join the service of the Corporation their subsisting pay and scale and other conditions of service and benefits to which they were entitled at that time would not be affected by the transfer

anchor.surface_text: The first term made it quite clear that when the employees of the erstwhile undertakings of the State would join the service of the Corporation their subsisting pay and scale and other conditions of service and benefits to which they were entitled at that time would not be affected by the transfer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal reading of condition No. 1 limits protection to pre-transfer entitlements
